segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Welcome to the annual DEFCON convention. This meeting was held in exciting Las Vegas, Nevada from July 9th through the 11th, 1999.
This is videotape number 52, Embedded Systems Hacking.
This is not going to be hacking into embedded systems.
This is actually going to be how to build yourself a nice little black box to assist in either hacking or denial of service or anything you really bloody want.
Actually a good segue was what we just saw previously with the wearable computers.
This is indeed a type of embedded system.
I'm not going to get into it because to be honest I know squat about video and it's basically all about video.
Everyone knows what an embedded system is.
I mean if it wasn't for it, embedded systems, telecommunications as we know it wouldn't exist already.
Modems, telephone switches, routers, everything that most people go through to get into the internet and get through the internet is in embedded systems.
Basically what this is, is a computer that's built into a box, usually no real accesses other than telnet, some sort of ethernet or T1 port.
There's no keyboard, there's no monitor and it does a very specialized purpose.
So it doesn't do 3 trillion things just like your PC does unfortunately.
Though some people end up throwing in little funny hooks.
If you know the right commands you can suddenly play Space Invaders on your modem.
But this is a little unusual.
Most people don't bother to do embedded systems even though these could be convenient in the hacking environment.
Specifically you can build a nice little small box that's easy to avoid and it's detection.
You can throw something in a Kleenex box.
No one knows what it is and you can be sitting there sniffing for all you want.
But no one seems to do it.
Partially it's because no one seems to be truly aware that they can build a nice little box or they don't think they have the skill set to do it.
It's really pretty easy nowadays.
There's actual, if you go into embedded systems journal on the back you've got demo boards.
These demo boards will have everything you want on it.
There's going to be a built in processor, you'll probably have an ethernet port, a T1 port.
All you have to do is put software on it.
And most manufacturers even provide software for you.
So it's not very difficult anymore.
Another problem most people consider involved with embedded systems is price.
Because you're actually going to have to buy all your individual components.
You're going to have to go out and get an i960.
You're going to have to go out and get a T1 chip.
Or you have to get the demo board.
Now one of the easiest ways to avoid the price thing is to salvage from old supports.
You've got a 386 sitting around that you've got no use for.
Haul out your soldering iron and yank that chip.
Find an old ethernet card, yank the chip there.
Suddenly you're not having to pay for components.
You just have to slap them all together.
Which is not that difficult.
In addition, a lot of manufacturers still offer their demo boards for free or for very little.
Because they want you to use their product.
And they think by offering this to you very conveniently,
that you are far more likely to go buy a lot of their product.
Okay, so we're not going to.
But they don't have to know that.
Now you do have to know where to be able to get these things.
If you're not going to be yanking them from your boards,
then you're going to have to find vendors and manufacturers.
You can go directly to the person who makes the chip.
You can go to Intel if you want an i960 or Motorola for a power PC.
But the chances are, they're not going to give you anything.
Because they don't care about the individual person.
You're going to have to find vendors.
The good news is, if you go onto a company's website,
they're going to list the vendors.
You give one of them a call up.
And most of them will end up sending you some sample chips.
One or two of the more expensive stuff, maybe 10, 12 cheaper stuff.
I've sometimes gotten e-prompts this way.
Call up enough vendors.
You can get a couple hundred if you need them.
Now there's plenty of uses for embedded systems.
One is to just be a sniffer.
You can monitor and record traffic or only specific traffic if you want.
One problem with this, with embedded systems over a standard computer on this,
would be storage.
Because you may not be able to come in and be able to yank your floppy
or a flash card or whatever you're going to be using regularly.
And you don't want to make this a huge box.
Another use for embedded systems would be denial of service.
You can actually build a box who will sit on the network for a day
collecting MAC addresses and IP addresses.
And then suddenly start spreading out garbage packets, large packets,
something else with a completely spoofed IP and a spoofed MAC address.
So that nobody knows where it's coming from.
And there's no real way to trace it back.
Because ideally, with a little bit of social engineering,
you've plugged it directly into somebody's network.
You can use this also to filter or block certain messages.
If you want to screw people up badly,
you can block everything from www.microsoft or whatever you want.
Just stick a little box in and just have all these things go into a black hole.
So there's plenty of uses for this.
One guy I was talking to yesterday is actually building a little keystroke recorder
that he wants to ideally fit into a keyboard.
So he'll just sit there and record every keystroke type on the keyboard.
Once again, this is quick, convenient, and something that embedded systems is ideal for.
Now there's going to be some fundamental skills if you're going to try and do embedded systems.
You're going to need to be able to program.
You need assembly.
You also probably need C.
Some people can do embedded systems completely in assembly,
but this is fairly rare nowadays.
Most everyone uses C once you get off the initial driver level.
So if you want to try and do this, know some assembly, know some C.
Those are the two main languages.
If you know Java, wonderful.
Go away.
You're also going to need some hardware knowledge.
You need to know which end of the soldering iron is hot.
Ideally, you need to know a little bit about how to wire a breadboard, what a breadboard is,
how to actually solder on chips, what a capacitor is.
Some basic, simple parts about hardware.
You're going to need to know how to get information on the chips you want and how to get samples.
Again, most of the time you can go straight to the manufacturer's website and get information.
They'll have the entire specs there.
They'll tell you how to get examples of sample code.
They'll tell you distributors.
You can find out how to get everything.
Another good source is the Embedded Systems Journal.
That thing, if you go back the last 20 pages of it, is basically all advertisements,
how to get yourself chips, demo boards, anything you really want that makes it easy for embedded systems.
There we go.
That's the basic overview of what the heck an embedded system is
and why you would actually want to do anything with it.
Let's get down to actually some details because you really want to know how to actually do this.
Let's start off with some processors.
You can start off with, I've got listed here first the main RISC processors.
There's the Intel i960.
Now, I personally don't like this.
I'm actually programming on it currently and I don't like the chip.
Part of the problem is with all Intel chips, you have a big ND and little ND issue.
Now, if you actually want your numbers to look like the numbers you intend them to be,
this is not the chip for you.
An additional problem with the i960 is it's expensive and there's nothing built into it.
It's just a microprocessor, which means if you want to have serial ports or anything else,
nothing's built into it.
You have to buy it all externally and hook it all in.
I don't like the i960.
However, everybody uses it.
There's compilers for it everywhere.
You can find a new C compiler that will do i960.
It's convenient.
Everyone knows how to do something with it generally.
There's a good knowledge base behind it.
There's one benefit with the i960.
Then we can go down to the Motorola Power PC, and this is actually better.
There's almost as much of a common base for it, almost as many people use the Power PC as the i960.
But unlike the i960, it actually does not have the big ND and little ND issue.
Your numbers come out nice and normal.
They have built-in SCCs, which are serial ports,
so that you can actually hook up other pieces of equipment to this
without having to do too much terrible engineering.
It's got DRAM controllers built in.
It's cheaper than the Intel.
Again, you can usually find compilers everywhere.
In fact, I use a GNU C compiler when I'm doing Power PC compiles.
If you want to go with a RISC chip, my personal preference would be the Motorola Power PC.
Another common RISC chip is the MIPS, but not many people use the MIPS.
It's got some built-ins to it.
The big problem with it is it's not very common.
It's not very sexy.
Of course, because of that, you're actually going to be able to get lots of samples of them
because the company is desperate to pawn them off on anybody.
So this is one benefit with the MIPS.
The MIPS is similar in construction to the Power PC.
It's got built-in DRAM controllers.
It's got built-in SCCs.
It does not have the big-endian, little-endian issue.
So if you're looking for just dirt cheap, a MIPS is probably where you want to go.
You can also then bow down to some of the lower-level processors.
There's the Intel 8051, which you can probably pick up for about,
depending on the speed of the processor, from anywhere from $1 to $10 a processor.
So it's very, very cheap, even if you're not getting samples.
The one problem is it doesn't have an awful lot of horsepower.
We're talking this is an 8-bit processor.
You can do some incredible things with it,
but you're probably going to have to write an assembly,
and you're going to have to write some really clever and some really tight code.
I've got friends that have implemented full 56K modems using it in 8051,
and that took a year and a half of engineering to end.
They were constantly having to tweak the code to keep the 8051 powerful enough to do this.
I mentioned earlier 386.
You can yank a 386 off of one of your motherboards and use that,
and you'll probably have enough power for what you want.
Some companies actually make what they call a PC on a chip,
and it's basically a 386 or a 486 on a small board,
usually with built-in serials and Ethernet ports.
You can go ahead and do that, but let's admit it.
I happen to think if you're going to use a PC chip, you're cheating.
We're talking embedded systems.
We're not trying to make this easy, okay?
So this basically covers processors.
Everyone's probably got a different processor they know of.
They've got different flavors that everyone likes.
Some people like the Pico.
Once again, use what you like.
There's plenty of them out there.
I'm just covering some of the basics.
When you come to IO devices, then you've got your basic Ethernet.
You've got a T1.
You even have wireless or AVSL if you want to get really exotic.
If you're going Ethernet, there's a lot of different Ethernet controllers out there.
My first preference is probably the Davicon chip because it's cheap.
Cheap is always a good thing.
You can always just yank off a familiar Ethernet card that you don't like anymore.
No one's using your old 16-bit ISA,
but that doesn't mean the chip is bad.
Depending on how old the card is, though, the chip may no longer be made,
in which case you're going to have some difficulties actually getting some specs on it.
So that's one thing to be aware of if you're actually going to recover from old hardware.
Just about everybody makes an Ethernet controller.
This makes it easy.
I went on the web and did a basic search.
There's the Davicon.
AMD makes one.
Cirrus Logic.
National Semiconductor.
You name the manufacturer of ICs
and they're probably going to make an Ethernet controller.
You can get 10 megabit controllers.
You can get 100 megabit.
You can get ones that'll switch from either way.
Personally, you're probably going to stick with a 10 megabit,
mostly because of price,
mostly because you have no need to go to 100 megabit Ethernet
for whatever situation you're going to be using for it.
T1 controllers are a little bit more tricky
because some T1 controllers you have to get two chips for,
specifically a line interface chip,
which is what actually connects up to the line and talks to it.
And then you have a framing chip,
which actually packetizes everything and sends it out.
So if you're going to be looking into doing something with T1 or even E1 applications,
you're going to want to check to see if you're going to be doing a single chip
or a multiple chip solution.
I'd recommend a single chip.
They tend to be cheaper than buying two separate chips.
Let's admit it.
It's easier if you've only got one chip to wire in than to do two chips.
One of the more popular single chip solutions would be the Siemens.
Well, it's now Etheon because Siemens split off their embedded systems group.
They make a very good T1 chip.
Cirrus Logic, on the other hand, does a two-chip solution,
which actually isn't bad if you want to go with a two-chip solution.
There's plenty of people at Goodwill who do wireless.
Cirrus Logic, actually, is another one who does it.
Once again, you can also do DSL.
Philips, AMD, National Center of Conductors,
everyone does DSL if you're interested in doing it.
But in general, when we're going to be doing some sort of little embedded systems box,
we're probably going to do some social engineering
and plug it directly into somebody's network.
You're most likely going to be interested in either Ethernet or T1, to be quite honest.
Or something that's completely standalone, doesn't hook into any of that,
in the case of the keyboard monitor.
It doesn't actually need to know anything about T1s.
It doesn't need to know anything about Ethernet.
It just needs to be able to hook into the keyboard.
So that's actually convenient.
It depends on what you're looking to do with your embedded program.
Now, when I'm talking about these things,
especially if we're talking about building some sort of a sniffer or recording device,
we've got a big memory problem,
because we're talking hundreds of thousands of packets going through
that we're going to suddenly have to record.
And this is one of the big problems we've got with embedded systems,
is trying to get enough memory at a reasonable price
that still makes your product small enough.
You can go out and get a hard drive and wire it on in,
but then you're talking, you've got extra size,
you've got a larger power requirement.
It's not really terribly convenient.
So what you're looking to do is you want to save to memory.
What's the best, most practical way of doing it?
You've got everything basically from a little flash chip,
where you can actually go write it onto a chip.
And then they're fairly small.
They're, I don't know, maybe about an inch long on average.
So you can get some nice small chips to write it in.
The only problem is when they're full up,
the only thing you can do is either yank the chips
or yank the board and put in a new board.
You can stick a floppy in,
but you've got the same problem as with a hard drive.
Once again, you've got more power requirements,
you've got size,
and you've still got to be able to go move the floppies in and out.
My personal preference is probably a flash card or a PCMCIA card.
You can get anything from about a 2MB to about a 32MB flash card.
You can hot swap them.
And it's fairly small,
so you're not talking about a lot of hardware to support it.
And it gives you the ability to just yank it out,
slap a new one in.
It takes very little amount of time.
And you can go home, stick it in your laptop,
and read what's actually been recorded on it.
There's another way to avoid recording at all,
and that is if you're hooked up to the network,
you can just transmit to yourself.
Have it hard-coded to record for an hour
and then send all the data to a certain IP address.
Do it over TFTP, perhaps.
So this is always a way to avoid on-memory solutions, too.
But remember, if you're going to be sending over the network,
somebody may start wondering how come their mail server
keeps sending 2GB of data every day to some strange IP address.
So I'm trying to be a little sensible about this.
In addition, if you're going to be building up a nice little embedded box,
you're going to have to throw some RAM on it.
Now the good news is that RAM is cheap.
So what you want to do,
it depends on how good of a coder you are when it comes down to it.
How tight are you writing the code?
How fast are you doing it?
And how much memory do you actually need to process what you're doing?
Depending on what you're doing,
I'd say anywhere from about 128K for something small,
which doesn't actually do an awful lot,
up to several megs.
The product I currently work on uses actually 64 megs of RAM.
And that's just for the main controller.
We're not talking the subcards.
Okay, well, you may think that I'm obscene,
but I don't expect most of you to have to deal with that.
You've got a question?
For an OS, you've got a choice.
If it's going to be something very simple that you're doing,
you can probably write something from the ground up.
There are several companies that provide OSs
designed specifically for embedded systems.
SourceCon does one.
Nucleus actually makes a very good OS.
If you take a look more on the free side,
Linux even comes with an embedded version that you can use.
And what's nice about Linux is that you can actually
Depending on what you're doing,
you may want to decide on scaling.
We wrote our own.
If you wanted to know,
it's an operating system that I currently use.
The company I work for, we wrote our own.
The previous companies I've worked for,
we tended to buy from Nucleus.
Nucleus is a company that I've worked for
for a long time,
The previous companies I've worked for,
we tended to buy from Nucleus.
Nucleus makes one of the best operating system kernels
around that I've seen.
It's fairly similar,
but it's designed specifically for embedded environments.
And it's clean, it's nice,
it has great debugging features.
And that's another thing you guys need to keep well.
You're going to have to debug this thing.
If you imagine you're going to slap it all together
and have it work first time through,
then you guys must be geniuses,
and I want you to come on up here and give the speech
because obviously you're better than I am.
I can't even write code that compiles cleanly
the first time, usually.
So, imagining that I could slap together
some sort of a box to do whatever I want
and have all the code and all the hardware work immediately
is fairly unlikely.
In fact, if you even take a look at the first production boards
of most companies,
you'll find that someone's been slapping on little wires here and there
to make up for the accidents they discovered
after they built the first batch.
Yes?
You're right.
Buying the little PC boards is the most practical way
because you don't have to worry about having hardware failures
and it gives you an easy development board.
I suppose the reason I call it cheating is because,
well, it seems a little easy to be honest.
I'm used to having to work with built-in microprocessors
and having to really engineer things from the ground up.
The PC boards are great, actually,
for the little home embedded systems programmer
because it's all there together,
it's very easy to put software together on it,
and it's really the simplest solution.
So, it's not really cheating,
I just find it a little too easy
to really qualify as true embedded systems.
Let's see, what have I got left?
I've covered most of the basics I wanted to do
because I wanted to keep this kind of short
so I could start answering questions.
I don't know how many of you have actually built something
or want to build something
or are wondering why the heck they're actually sitting here still.
Does anybody really have any questions?
Okay, you, black shirt.
You can do that,
and there are actually some people that have built such.
Ethernet and phone lines in particular,
both of which provide more power
than you actually need for the protocol.
You're going to have to be careful though.
Most of them, you build it to power off of them,
but there's enough of a variance
in the actual real-life use
that sometimes it won't work.
One company I worked for built a little modem
that was powered off of a phone line,
and it worked on about 70% of the phone lines.
The rest of them were bouncing around enough
on the power selections that you actually had to plug in
a 9-volt battery.
So just remember you're working in the real world,
and not everyone's going to actually follow the spec.
How long have I been doing embedded systems?
I've been doing it for about 6 1⁄2 years.
I started off in the modem industry.
I'm now in the telecommunications industry.
I specialize mostly in protocols,
currently in frame rate variations.
Oh, boy.
Everyone over here seems to like me.
We'll just start with you in the back,
with the big build.
One-tip solutions.
There are some of them out there.
The ones that I have played with, I have hated.
I find them generally pretty flaky.
They always decide to do strange things
and give out on you at the last moment,
usually in those critical moments.
They've gotten better,
and I haven't played with them in a couple years now,
and I'm told they've gotten better.
But I've been really pretty unimpressed.
Everyone who tries to slam everything onto one chip
tends to leave things out.
Next.
This side's obviously pretty quiet.
Who?
I missed you.
Okay, we'll give you.
We're doing some sort of a solution
where everything's added on via serial ports.
This is actually pretty good.
You can do an awful lot of things with serials.
Everything from HDLC to just slapping on another chip.
It's very convenient.
It's very quick.
If you're going to do that,
you want to make sure that whatever your microprocessor is,
it has a lot of SCCs to handle it.
Motorola tends to slap about four of them on a chip.
MIPS tends to put about two on.
You don't want to use an Intel i960.
They don't put SCC ports on their chips.
Each SCC port is going to do
some sort of a serial interface for you.
If you need a lot of serial interfaces,
what I've actually seen people do
is they actually enslave a second Motorola PowerPC chip
to the original one
just so that they can use the SCC ports.
Next.
It depends on what you're doing.
When I was doing modems,
I was the sole programmer for the entire modem code base.
I then branched out.
I have worked on teams from anywhere from about two people to...
The current team I'm on would be a little hard to describe.
My current chunk of it, I'm the only one working on it,
but we've got hundreds of programmers
working in the code base constantly.
For some of the little things that you're doing,
especially if you're going to use something along the lines of a PC-on-a-chip
or some sort of a demo board
where you've already got some software built in,
you can probably do it on your own in a couple months
if you're a decent programmer
and you know what you're doing
and you can read a spec.
Right.
Ideally, if you're not that good at hardware,
and God knows the hardware guys don't like me in their lab,
your best bet is to buy some sort of pre-made solution,
which means either a PC-on-a-chip or a demo board.
There's hundreds of demo boards out there
using various different chip sets
with various interfaces.
You can very commonly find for somewhere between $20 and $70
a board with a microprocessor,
an Ethernet chip, and a T1 chip on it.
So you've already got just about everything you could need
to hook into a network right there.
They'll give you the power supply information.
Usually it's like a 9-volt transformer you can just plug into a wall.
You can gen up something independent if you actually want,
but you can actually get a nice little box that has everything in it,
and all you've got to do is slap on some code
and put something around it so it doesn't look like
this piece of circuit board flying around,
which may actually make somebody suspicious.
Okay, we'll go with you.
Most of them don't actually deal with the protocols at all.
If you want to be able to read the TCP IP headers
or determine what's actually within the data packet,
you're going to have to write that all into your own software.
Right, that's where you really want to be able to do the controlling of it anyway.
Most Ethernet chips are only going to do the basics.
It's going to be reading the data and give it to you in a format
that you can actually then read and process.
You can actually buy Ethernet chips that will do switching,
but I don't see any of you really wanting to build a box
that's just going to switch the Ethernet out.
But, yeah, I suppose there's possibilities.
You can get switched Ethernet chips.
You can get ones that are just going to be able to input and output.
Single-chip Ethernet's a do-lander.
You can find some, yeah.
In fact, Ethernet, you're far more likely to find a single-chip solution
than in T1 specifically.
So if you're going to be doing some sort of an Ethernet solution,
if it's not being offered in a single-chip solution,
don't go with the company.
Okay, we'll go all the way over there, black shirt.
Yes, you.
Okay, preferences for compilers and where to get unchipped samples.
For compilers, the past couple of companies I've worked at,
we've actually used one flavor or another of GANUSI.
It works well.
You can customize it out.
It's pretty nice, to be quite honest,
and you can get them to run with just about any microprocessor that you want to use.
If you're going to go away from GANUSI,
you're probably going to have to pay some money for the compiler.
So I recommend, unless you really can't stand it, stick with the GANU.
As for unchipped samples,
I don't know off the top of my head where you can get them,
but I would recommend if you've got a specific vendor that you want to go through,
you find out who one of their distributors are,
and you start calling distributors.
At least one of them will give you samples, maybe only a single one.
But most people are so desperate to get your business,
that they will send you samples.
Oh my, there's another person from this side.
They're actually starting to get spunky over here.
Why don't you go for it?
Depends on which, he wants to know about Ethernet chips,
whether they'll give you access to the packet as it's arriving,
or whether they'll wait to receive the entire packet before they send it to you.
Usually you can get access to it as it's arriving.
So you can start tweaking it almost instantaneously.
They're going to throw it in probably into some sort of a ring buffer or shared memory
that you can just start reading as soon as it starts putting any information in there.
Okay, he wants to know whether I have to reload code onto my products
when I'm doing debugging, or if I've got some sort of an emulation.
And the answer is it really depends on the scope of what I'm doing.
The larger the project, the more likely I'm going to be loading the code on it every single time,
because I'm probably going to have flash,
and it's probably easier to stick something,
plug something in like a logic analyzer just to watch things.
The smaller it is, the more likely I am to actually do
some sort of offline emulation, to be quite honest.
A lot of people like GDB. I can't stand it.
If you're going to actually plug some sort of an emulator in,
it's going to cost money, because to get an emulator,
people don't give these things away as samples, unfortunately.
You can do a software emulator, which is going to get you a certain amount of information,
but eventually you're going to have to run it on your actual product,
which means if you're trying to do it in one-time blend proms,
you're probably going to have to burn, I don't know, half a dozen to a dozen of a minimum.
If you're going to be doing it on something that's erasable or flashable,
it's not that inconvenient.
You might be able to get your hands on something that will actually plug in
and pretend to be the prom,
in which case you're talking some sort of a hardware emulator.
Applied Microsystems makes a couple of really good ones, to be honest,
but you're going to be paying money.
These things don't come cheap.
We're talking about $10,000.
If you want to do this, make friends with some sort of a software or hardware engineer
and get them to let you into their labs on the weekends.
Okay, go for it.
Okay, this is about debugging and how much effort is actually involved in debugging.
Depending on what kind of a solution you're going with
depends on how much debugging you're going to be doing.
If you're doing a very well-known microprocessor,
your debugging time is probably going to go down a little bit,
because let me warn you, there are going to be bugs that you find
that just aren't in the manufacturer's documents.
And sometimes you'll never convince them that they've actually got a problem.
So the more well-known the processor,
the less likely you are to run into undocumented problems in their hardware.
If you buy a pre-made solution, some sort of a demo board,
there's less likely that you're going to actually have hardware problems,
so you can remove those as another time saver.
This leaves you just trying to figure out what the heck your software is doing
and when you actually tweak this pin,
does the hardware actually do what it says it's supposed to do.
And it doesn't always.
Once again, the longer it's been out, the less likely you are to find out that
even though they say this one pin can be floating,
you always have to keep it grounded if you actually want it to seem over the first 32K of memory.
Assuming that you've got all the hardware problems worked out,
on the software, you can do a good chunk of software-based emulation.
GDB, once again, we're going to go with the free stuff, is not bad.
I don't like it, mostly because I've used some of the really nifty hardware-based debugging,
and I'm spoiled.
But if you want a real cheap, simple solution,
GDB in itself will probably take care of 80% of all your problems.
Eventually, you're going to have to run this on the actual hardware real-time.
And the problem when you start doing this is,

Usually what's happening is you end up writing your code probably two months before there's actually any hardware for you to stick it on.
You're hoping and praying that the hardware will actually get done before you get to the point
where you cannot write any more code.
When that happens, you slap your code on and you spend the next three months

It's really painful if you don't have already well-developed hardware

whether it's software, whether it's hardware, and whether it's easier to fix in software or hardware.

So there will quite often be knock-down, drag-out fights with people screaming at each other

and the hardware guy refuses to fix it in his code.

But in general, it's going to probably take two to three months for a large board.

The software usually is going to take longer.
Unfortunately, sometimes there will be a hardware bug that will not show up
until many months actually into the development and debugging cycles.
